title: Trailing newlines affect spans

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-parser
labels.description: Area: The parsing of Rust source code to an AST.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Trailing newlines affect the locations and spans of error messages. For instance:
```shell
echo -n '#[i=i::a' > test.rs
```
produces (when compiling `test.rs` with rustc):
```
error: this file contains an unclosed delimiter
 --> test.rs:1:9
  |
1 | #[i=i::a
  |  -      ^
  |  |
  |  unclosed delimiter

error: expected item after attributes
 --> test.rs:1:1
  |
1 | #[i=i::a
  | ^^^^^^^^

error: aborting due to 2 previous errors
```
Which is what I would expect. However, the same code with a trailing newline:
```shell
echo '#[i=i::a' > test.rs
```
produces:
```
error: this file contains an unclosed delimiter
 --> test.rs:1:10
  |
1 | #[i=i::a
  |  -       ^
  |  |
  |  unclosed delimiter

error: expected item after attributes
 --> test.rs:1:1
  |
1 | #[i=i::a
  | ^^^^^^^^^

error: aborting due to 2 previous errors
```
where the first error message points to nowhere (position `test.rs:1:10` does not exist), and the span of the second error message is too wide by one character. This initially confused me quite a bit, because it looks like an invisible character in the source file, or an issue with a multibyte character or something. I think that the trailing newline should either be ignored, or that the error should locate EOF in line 2 (and not 1, _after_ the newline, which is at `test.rs:1:9`).
